Award.AwardTitle: Outsourcing, Offshoring, and Performance: A Data Set and Analysis of Production Sourcing Decisions in the Semiconductor Industry since 1990

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project the Principal Investigators will examine the causes and consequences of outsourcing and offshoring decisions. Specifically, the research will integrate models from organizational economics with models from organization theory to examine a series of questions associated with the de-integration and globalization of the semiconductor industry. By jointly examining ownership and location decisions this research will provide precise statements regarding the primary factors driving these critical investment decisions and clarify important conceptual associations between exchange characteristics (that create different coordination and control challenges) and organizational forms (that emphasize different coordinating and control solutions). The longitudinal nature of the examination will provide a test of the stability of these associations. In addition, by providing evidence regarding the influence of the alignment between the underlying attributes of exchanges and discrete organizational solutions on innovative (e.g., measures of the frequency of product and process innovation) and financial (e.g., return on invested capital, return on sales) performance measures this study provides a foundation for more integrative research on the implications of organizational governance. Finally, by exploring the persistence of any performance advantages (or disadvantages) associated with these decisions, the findings may suggest heretofore unrecognized temporal tradeoffs associated with these decisions.

In terms of broader impacts, this research will contribute to both managerial decision-making and public policy. The results may provide new insights about the short- and long-term performance implications of offshoring and outsourcing decisions under various conditions that will aid managers and policy makers who are concerned with production sourcing decisions. Also, this project will develop protocols that other scholars can use to analyze a publicly available database of information describing financial and organizational decisions in this industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

NSF Award #1133043

This project addresses the causes and consequences of governance (e.g., make or buy) and location (e.g., in which country to locate an activity) choices. More simply, this project examines "outsourcing" and "offshoring" decisions.

While both governance and location choices have received substantial independent attention, little work has explored the interdependence between these two decisions. If these choices are interdependent, then overemphasizing one aspect of the decision may lead to significant errors.  By jointly examining these decisions, this research provides precise statements regarding the primary factors driving governance and location choices and clarifies important associations between characteristics of the underlying tasks (that create different coordination and control challenges), organizational forms (that emphasize different incentive, leadership, monitoring, and dispute resolution policies), locations (which imply different levels of cost, access to expert talent, intellectual property protection, and coordination challenges), and performance.

In order to address these goals, the project developed an extensive dataset, trained multiple students, and developed research papers aimed at addressing three underlying research questions. The project deliverables exceeded expectations—the project delivered more data than expected, trained more students than expected, and delivered statistically and economically significant research findings. The primary research questions and findings are below.

  1. Are vertical scope (make or buy) and geographic scope (location of work) decisions interdependent? Does any observed interdependence affect our understanding of the primary factors associated with these decisions?

    A research paper written by Michael Leiblein, Marcus Larsen, and Torben Pedersen supports the conjecture that governance and location decisions are interdependent. The results presented in this paper demonstrate how controlling for the interdependence between governance and location decisions affects associations between task- (e.g., problem structure, demand uncertainty), firm- (e.g., size, experience), and location- (e.g., wage, technological sophistication) attributes and these choices.
  2. What are the performance consequences of vertical and geographic scope decisions? Does any observed interdependence affect our understanding of the short-term performance consequences of these decisions?

    A research paper by Michael Leiblein and Kiran Awate demonstrates how the interdependence of governance (e.g., make or buy) and location (e.g., nation-state) choices affects technological performance after controlling for a broad set of characteristics. For instance, semiconductor firms in our sample that decide to “buy” a product in the USA outperform those that “make” in the USA; however firms that decide to “buy” in France underperform those that decide to “make” a similar product in France. The paper also decomposes the nation-state effect to demonstrate the influence of underlying nation-state characteristics (e.g., National Culture or National Innovation Policies).
  3. What are the long-term performance consequences of these decisions? Do these choices affect the persistence of any advantage or disadvantage?

    A research paper by Tammy Madsen and Michael Leiblein demonstrates associations between internal experience, collaborative effort (e.g., alliances), patenting, and the persistence of superior performance. The main finding is that internal experiences are most strongly associated with the persistence of superior innovation activity. In unpublished findings, we also show that the persistence of superior innovation activity is associated with the persistence of superior financial performance. Michael Leiblein and John Gray (co-PI on this grant) have discussed a paper that more specifically addresses the effect of governance and location choices on the persistence of technical advantage. Travis Whetsell and Michael Leiblein are exploring whether and how large Defense Department funded consortiums (e.g., JESSI, Sematech) affect subsequent research collaborations and advantage over time. Michael Leiblein, Jeff Macher, and Tiberiu Ungureanu have written a book chapter that examines why small firms systematically benefit less from collaborative activity than large firms.

In sum, this project demonstrates implications of the interdependence between choices concerning the governance and location of an activity. This interdependence influences important decisions-- in informal terms it affects whether one should “outsource” or “offshore” a particular activity. This interdependence has significant performance implications. Our findings indicate that global semiconductor firms, on average, benefit by outsourcing production but there are significant differences in the nature of this effect across countries and “distance” between a firm’s headquarters and activity location. These organizational choices also have long-term performance implications. It appears that some managers may be underestimating how much today’s organizational choices influence the set of next-generation options available to their firms. They may be inadvertently hollowing out their technological capabilities while focusing on current wage levels, political concerns, or tax efficiency considerations.
